div1.p: Peabody describes the research material he left at the Welch Medical Library. He mentions that Agramonte's daughter has many of her father's documents.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Philip Showalter Hench, September 20, 1940
div1.p:
Many thanks for your kind
letter of the 18th. which contains a
great deal of very interesting material.
Evidently you have made some val-
uable discoveries with reference to
this Yellow Fever story. It is fortunate
that you are able to straighten
out conflicting tales and to put
the true account into print while
you can consult the authorities. When
I was in Cuba I met Dr. Agramonte's
daughter and she told me she
had a trunk full of documents
which her father had collected. She
told me I was free to use this in
any way I wished. Unfortunately
my brief stay in Havana made
this impossible. I am sorry that
I cannot give you her address,
Ac
NP
but I am quite sure you would
find it in the folder I left at
the Welch Medical Library in
Baltimore.

I made no list of the material
I left there. I remember it con-
tained Kissinger's original yellow
fever chart, letters from Mrs. Reed,
Mrs. Lazear, Mrs. Carroll, Mrs,
Agramonte and her daughter,
Moran & Kissinger, photographs,
and if I mistake not the biblio-
graphy to which you refer, Col.
Garrison who was then librarian,
had this folder put in a safe.
It was labelled Yellow Fever Material,
so it must be possible to locate it,
If you think it would help you
in any way, I should be glad
indeed if you would ask them
to send it all to you by express.

I shall be very glad to receive
reprints of the addresses you are
preparing.
div1.closer: Very truly yours. James E. Peabody.
